Lehrstuhl Huber Lehrstuhl Huber Internal | Search | About Home Events People Teaching Research Non-adiabatic light-matter coupling Quantum electronics THz nonlinear optics Publications Contact Department of Physics > LS Huber > AG Huber > Research Ultrafast quantum dynamics and photonics Our scientific focus is set on ultrafast phenomena dominating the physics of solids, molecules and custom tailored nanostructures. We aim to understand and control the microscopic interplay between elementary degrees of freedom and exploit this knowledge to design quantum systems with novel functionalities. As the essential tool box, we conceive highly intense sources of ultrashort phase-locked laser pulses as well as field-sensitive detectors for the entire infrared and terahertz window of the electromagnetic spectrum. Similarly to an extreme slow motion camera, this technology allows us to capture and control elementary quantum dynamics on the femtosecond scale (1 fs = 1015 s). In particular, the availability of record-intense and ultrashort electric and magnetic field transients allows us to study matter under unprecedented high-field conditions and reach an extremely non-adiabatic limit of light-matter interaction. Exciting new pathways to quantum electronics, quantum optics and quantum electrodynamics have been opened. Our current list of projects includes: Ultrastrong and non-adiabatic light-matter coupling Quantum electronics of strongly correlated materials Terahertz nonlinear optics Femtosecond photonics Please, take a look at our publications for a comprehensive overview over our latest results. Last modified: 22.02.2011 by Webmaster

ue6Ess02.html ue6Ess02.html > # EXERCISES ON THEOR. PH. II (ELECTRODYNAMICS and OPTICS) > # Prof. Dr.U. Krey, Univ. Regensburg, Juan-Diego Urbina, Rainer H?llinger; summer 2002, file 6 > # Topics: Alternating currents (impedances); MAPLE (a typical 'MAPLE worksheet') > #------------------------------------------------------------------------ > # Problem 11 : Complex impedance ; resonance effects > #------------------------------------------------------------------------ > # Consider a serial RLC circuit composed (i) of an Ohmic resistance R, > # (ii) a capacitive resistance (plate) with capacity C > # and (iii) an inductive resistance (solenoid) with inductivity L. > # This circuit forms the load attached > # to the poles of an alternating voltage generator, with the generator voltage U~(t) := U_0 * cos ( w*t) > # (U_0=220 Volt = amplitude of the generator voltage; w = 2*Pi*f = circular frequency; > # f = 50 Hz). For the current through the RLC serial load > # we thus obtain I(t) = I_0 * cos ( w*t-alpha), with > # I_0/U_0 = 1/sqrt(R^2+(w*L-1/(w*C))^2) #( = 1/|RR|, 1/abs(RR), current resonance) and > # alpha = arctan( ( w*L-1/(w*C) ) /R) #( = arctan (Im(RR)/Re(RR), phase resonance), > # with the complex ac resistance (impedance) RR := R + I*(w*L-1/(w*C)). I is the 'imaginary unit' (I^2=-1), whereas II is the current. > # Basic part, A: > # Please calculate and plot the current and phase resonance curves > # for various values of the Ohmic resistance R for C=1 Farad and L=1 Henry as a function of the > # reduced frequency w_red := w/w_0, with the resonance frequency w_0 :=1/sqrt{L*C} > # Solution (proposal, in mksA units): > ## R1 := 0.2; R2 := 0.1 ; R3 := 0.05;#(Ohm). (With the execution here and below the twofold '##' symbols should be deleted !!) > # > ## L := 1; #(Henry) > ## C := 1; #(Farad) > ## f1(w):= 1/ sqrt( R1*R1 +(w*L-1/(w*C))^2); f2(w):= 1/sqrt( R2*R2 + (w*L-1/(w*C))^2); f3(w):= 1/sqrt(R3*R3+(w*L-1/(w*C))^2); > # In units of Hz the frequency w is equal to w_red > ## plot ( { f1(w),f2(w),f3(w)} , w=0 .. 2); > ## alpha1(w) := arctan ( (w*L-1/(w*C))/R1 ); alpha2(w) := arctan ( (w*L-1/(w*C))/R2 );alpha3(w) := arctan ( (w*L-1/(w*C))/R3 ); > ## plot ( {alpha1(w), alpha2(w), alpha3(w)}, w = 0 .. 2 ); > # Phase resonance : For the resonance frequency (w=w_red=1) > # current and voltage are exactly 'in phase'; for lower frequencies > # the current is ahead of the voltage, alpha ? 0; for higher frequencies > # the current is behind the voltage (alpha ? 0) > # > # Second part, B: Please exploit systematically the possibility to calculate with complex numbers ( z:=x+I*y; Re(z);...; abs(z) ) > # Third part, C: Please try similar calculations (e.g., by variation of the complex quantities RR, UU, II etc.) > # for at least one further load, which is obtained from R , I*w*L und 1/(I*w*C) - [I is the imaginary unit, whereas II is the current] - > # by the formation of parallel or mixed circuits or with additional mutual inductivities (transformer). > # (In the last case, we have on the one hand for the complex input voltage of the transformer the result (UU_Tr)^(1)=I*w*L_{12}*(II)^(2), > # on the other hand the output voltage of the transformer is (UU_Tr)^(2)= - I*w*L_{21}*(II)^(1) = [R_2+I*(w*L_2-1/(w*C_2))]*(II)^(2). > # Altogether, with L_{12}=L_{21} : (RR)^(1)(w) =(UU)_~/(II)^(1) = R+I*(w*L-1/(w*C)) + w^2*L_{12}^2 /[R_2+I*(w*L_2-1/(w*C_2))] ) > #------------------------------------------------------------ > # Problem 12) Potential lines: 3d contour plots > #------------------------------------------------------------ > # The electrostatic potential of a positive point charge Q in vacuo > # at a distance Dx=1 to the l.h.s. in front of (!) a metal plane (y-z-plane at x=0) and the oppositely charged induced (fictitious) > # mirror image at the same distance to the r.h.s. (!) of that plane > # is (apart from a factor Q/(4*pi*eps_0)) in the plane z=0 given by : > # > ## Phi := (x,y) -> 1/(sqrt((x+1)^2+y^2))-1/(sqrt((x-1)^2+y^2)) ; > # > # The equipotential lines of this potential are obtained with : > # > ## plot3d( Phi, -2..2, -1..1 , view = -4..4, axes=box, style=patchcontour ); > # ( x-values between -2 and +2, y-values between -1 and +1; Phi-values between -4 and +4 ) > ########################################################################### > # ( You can rotate the plot and export it into Word or TeX documents ! ) > # > # First task: Produce similar plots for different potentials, e.g. for the > # potential of a constant electrostatic field which is deformed by a metallic sphere > # ( respectively of the analogous case of a current flow vec(j), with vec(j) ~ vec(E) ) : > ## Phii := (x,y) -> if x^2+y^2 > 1 then x * ( 1 - 1/(sqrt(x*x+y*y))^3 ) else 0 fi ; > # > ## plot3d( Phii , -3 .. 3 , -2 ..2, axes=box, style=patchcontour ); > ######################## ######################## ########################
